explanations.b: Incorrect! Around most of the distribution lies in the $-2\sigma$ to $2\sigma$ range.

questions.question: A random variable $X$ follows a standard normal distribution and another random variable $Y$ is given as $Y = 3\cdot X +2$. If we know $\mu_X=0$ and $\sigma_X=1$, then what are the mean ($\mu_Y$) and standard-deviation ($\sigma_Y$) of Y?

Let $X \sim N(0, I_2)$ be a two-dimensional standard normal random vector, where $I_2$ is the $2\times2$ identity matrix. What is the distribution of $Y = AX$, where $A = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$?

explanations.a: Incorrect! The covariance matrix is not the identity after applying the transformation $A$.
explanations.b: Correct! The new covariance matrix is $A \Sigma_X A^T$, which results in $\begin{bmatrix} 5 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$, as $\Sigma_X = I_2$.
explanations.c: Incorrect! You need to multiply $A$ and its transpose to get the correct covariance matrix.
explanations.d: Incorrect! The mean vector of $Y$ is still zero since $X$ is centered at zero.

questions.question: Let $X \sim N(\mu_X, \Sigma_X)$ be a Gaussian random vector in $\mathbb{R}^3$, where $\mu_X = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \\ 3 \end{bmatrix}$ and $\Sigma_X = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0.5 & 0 \\ 0.5 & 2 & 0.3 \\ 0 & 0.3 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$. Find the marginal distribution of $X_1$ and $X_3$.

explanations.a: Correct! The marginal distribution of $X_1$ and $X_3$ is obtained by selecting the corresponding submatrix of $\Sigma_X$.
explanations.b: Incorrect! You may have neglected to calculate the covariance matrix correctly.
explanations.c: Incorrect! The marginal covariance is different.
explanations.d: Incorrect! Check the submatrix corresponding to $X_1$ and $X_3$.

questions.question: When does a bivariate Gaussian pdf has negative covariance?

answers.a: When the slope of the principal axis of its pdf is positive
answers.b: When the slope of the principal axis of its pdf is negative
answers.c: When the slope of the principal axis of its pdf is 0

explanations.a: Correct! Negative slope means negative covariance.
explanations.d: Incorrect! Covariance depends upon the slope of the principal axis (Hint : Refer to Isocontours section of Theory).

questions.question: For any $x \in \mathbb{R}$, what is the relationship between $\Phi(-x)$ and $\Phi(x)$?

explanations.a: Correct! The CDF of a standard normal distribution has the symmetry property $\Phi(-x) = 1 - \Phi(x)$ due to the symmetry of the normal distribution.
explanations.b: Incorrect! This would imply that the CDF is the same for positive and negative values, which is not true.
explanations.c: Incorrect! The CDF cannot be negative.
explanations.d: Incorrect! The relationship is not multiplicative or inverse in this way.
